RSAccess 0.1.0
  • Reference

A simple features data frame with regular hexagons classified into 6 spatial patterns. In order to obtain this classification, we employed a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to reduce the dimension of a dataset. Then, using only the first thirty-five principal components, we carried out an unsupervised classification to identify groups that represent the distinct spatial patterns within the GGH. Each final cluster can be interpreted as a distinct spatial pattern with unique levels of built-up area density, land use, and street layout. The polygons were classified into: 1 - "High Building Density"; 2 - "Tree-lined Neighborhoods"; 3 - "Medium Building Density"; #' 4 - "Mixed Rural Use"; 5 - "Waterfront Housing"; 6 - "Farms and Rural Neighborhoods"

Source: R/RSAccess-package.R
grid_classified.Rd

A simple features data frame with regular hexagons classified into 6 spatial patterns. In order to obtain this classification, we employed a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to reduce the dimension of a dataset. Then, using only the first thirty-five principal components, we carried out an unsupervised classification to identify groups that represent the distinct spatial patterns within the GGH. Each final cluster can be interpreted as a distinct spatial pattern with unique levels of built-up area density, land use, and street layout. The polygons were classified into: 1 - "High Building Density"; 2 - "Tree-lined Neighborhoods"; 3 - "Medium Building Density"; #' 4 - "Mixed Rural Use"; 5 - "Waterfront Housing"; 6 - "Farms and Rural Neighborhoods"

A simple features data frame with all attributes used during the classification process. In order to obtain this dataset, we extracted features from satellite images and from a road network shapefile. We employed a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to reduce the dimension of a dataset. Then, using only the first thirty-five principal components, we carried out an unsupervised classification to identify groups that represent the distinct spatial patterns within the GGH.

A simple features data frame with Spatial Access Measures (SAM). In order to obtain this dataset, we transferred the SAM data from the dissemination blocks to the cell grid using a weighted area interpolation. This technique enables us to disaggregate accessibility values to another spatial unit, smoothing variations between polygons. It achieves this by using the area of overlapping geometries to apportion variables.

A simple features data frame with Spatial Access Measures (SAM) and the spatial patterns classification.

Usage

data(grid_classified)

data(grid_classified)

data(grid_classified)

data(grid_classified)

Format

A simple features data frame with 53,609 rows and 2 variables:

id

unique identifier for each polygon.

Cluster

space pattern classification

A simple features data frame with 53,609 rows and 228 variables:

id

unique identifier for each polygon.

BP_min

minimum value of built-up area

BP_max

maximum value of built-up area

BP_mean

average value of built-up area

BP_sum

sum of built-up area

BP_std

standard deviation of built-up area

BP_median

median value of built-up area

BP_majorit

majority value of built-up area

minimum value of building height

Cluster

space pattern classification

A simple features data frame with 53,609 rows and 5 variables:

id

unique identifier for each polygon.

cy_ac_emp

normalised value of a cell's access to employment (Cycling mode)

pto_ac_emp

normalised value of a cell's access to employment (Publit transit (off peak) mode)

ptp_ac_emp

normalised value of a cell's access to employment (Publit transit (on peak) mode)

wa_ac_emp

normalised value of a cell's access to employment (Walking mode)

A simple features data frame with 13,097 rows and 5 variables:

id

unique identifier for each polygon.

Cluster

space pattern classification

cy_ac_emp

normalised value of a cell's access to employment (Cycling mode)

pto_ac_emp

normalised value of a cell's access to employment (Publit transit (off peak) mode)

ptp_ac_emp

normalised value of a cell's access to employment (Publit transit (on peak) mode)

wa_ac_emp

normalised value of a cell's access to employment (Walking mode)

Examples

 data(grid_classified)
 clusters <- grid_classified$Cluster
 data(grid_with_attributes)
 built_up_mean <- grid_with_attributes$BP_mean
 data(grid_sam)
 cycling <- grid_sam$cy_ac_emp
 data(grid_sam_classified)
 cycling <- grid_sam_classified$cy_ac_emp
